Meditation: A Perspective from affective neuroscience

Meditation, from focal meditation to mindfulness entails the avoidance of all conscious discursive or unpredictable transitive (act-outcome) or ‘what if’ decision making or judgment that represents past, present and future judgments that can easily transition into perseverative thought (i.e. regret, distraction, and worry). In other words, meditation is reducing discursive thinking by being in the moment or ‘mindful’. The avoidance of discursive thinking or ‘mind wandering’ prevents the development of future perseverative conflicts and results in the covert musculature becoming inactive, or a pleasurable state of rest. Relaxation is achieved by avoiding discursive judgment rather than all judgment, while anticipated and subsequent non-discursive or meaningful behavior sustains and enhances the positive affect due to relaxation both during and after meditation sessions. (This is exemplified in cognitive strategies such as savoring, loving-kindness meditation, and flow experiences that couple positive ideation with relaxed states, and its neurobiology is discussed in the link below) Thus meditation, to be effective or most ‘affective’, must represent a dual cognitive strategy that couples the inhibition of discursive thinking with subsequent non-discursive or meaningful judgment or thought.


A more formal explanation from a neurologically based learning theory is provided on pp. 47-52 in a little open-source book on the psychology of rest linked below. (The flow experience is discussed on pp. 81-86.)
https://www.scribd.com/doc/284056765/The-Book-of-Rest-The-Odd-Psychology-of-Doing-Nothing

Meditation isn't always suitable for everyone. In most cases it is talked up as only positive, without even acknowledging any of the possible negative experiences that could come up. Medications have a list of negative side effects on the box so we know what could happen if we take those meds. Meditation should be no different.

Here is my experience with mindful meditation:
My Psychologist asked me to try mindfulness meditation to help with my anxiety and depression. She done a 3 minute breathing meditation with me in-session to show me what to do, which went okay, apart from feeling silly and a bit bored. I was then asked to meditate for 3-5 minutes daily at home for the following week. This is when my problems started.

First day doing it alone triggered my anxiety to a near panic attack. I tried to continue for the rest of the week, thinking it would get better over time. By the end of the week I wasn't just experiencing anxiety, but remembering disturbing memories from a time I was really struggling with depression and suicidal thoughts. Everything came rushing back - all the feelings and emotions from that time, and I started to have suicidal thoughts again, which hadn't bothered me for years.

While I respect meditation can help people, it doesn't help everyone. Psychologists handing out meditation like candy to people who are already mentally unstable can do a lot more harm than good, given their predisposition to triggers and trauma memories.
I wish they would show the dark side to meditation. Like anything, it's not for everyone. It can lead to psychosis or dissociative disorders for some people. Not a lot of people, but still some

WRONG PRONUNCIATION: It's AUM not OM. Why?
-> Om is basically a monosyllabic word, as compared to Aum, which is tri-syllabic. This is because of the difference in the way the two words are pronounced. Om is simply pronounced the way it is written. Against this, Aum is pronounced as aa-uu-eemm.

In Sanskrit, ‘O’ is a diphthong sound. This means that it is formed by combining the two sounds ‘A’ and ‘U’. The difference between the two variations, Aum and Om, developed only due to transliteration.

"Meditation" is an umbrella term, a category that includes all sorts of different practices. Not all of them work. Not all of them are aimed at the same thing, so we have to be careful how we compare them. And among the ones that do aim at the same thing, not all of them are equally effective, and not all of them are meant to be practiced by the same populations. That's why we need a lot of careful research before we make claims about meditation, and making blanket claims like in this video is almost always a bad idea.

Hello! Sorry to interrupt guys. I believe this is confusing and unaccurate, especially when talking about the Default Mode Network. The DMN is precisely what you're attempting to DE-activate during meditation. The excess of default mode network operating is related to the autobiographical self (thinking of oneself in relation to past or future, rumination, possibly anxiety, and through some scientific evidence, even associated with MDD). To clear it up: The DMN activates itself when the mind is in a negative-task state, whereas meditation has everything to do with a positive-task state; in other words, actively using the mind's attention and focus. Hence the sanskrit word, ''ekagatta' which roughly translates to ''single-pointed focus''.

Meditation Guide for "Newbies":
1) There are many ways of practicing meditation, but first, you need to understand the real purpose of it which is to shut down your mind, therefore it won't produce thoughts unless you do need them for practical actions. Yes, that means that you are not your mind, the mind is just a tool but we don't get to learn that in school. So, meditation helps you to stay "Conscious", and also help you use your mind when you do need it and shut the excessive thoughts if you do not need them, because otherwise, that's how you start getting negative thoughts and therefore negative emotions, energy, etc. On a spiritual level, and also the reason why by meditating we are trying to shut down the mind is to feel your "True" you, to understand that there is a higher intelligence than the mind and that this last one is just a tool for practical daily use, like solving math problems, but the mind is not good for other things like Love, and Relationships with any living being. So yes, it does improve your life not just physically and emotionally but also and most importantly in every aspect of your life. Sounds amazing right? and it only takes 20 minutes every day <3! In case you want a good book that combines science, spirituality, meditation and life, go read the Power Of Now, a lot of CEOs and entrepeneurs put that book as a must read, me too, its amazing :D!!
2) After knowing the basics I just told you, you can easily know that if you just sit down in front of a wall and try not to think, you will be practicing "Meditation". But wait, that is a hard way of doing it, especially for beginners. Thus, there are easier ways and I will give you some examples:
3) First and easiest Example: most common around the world, is to sit down, cross your legs like in the movies, and concentrate on your breathing; thus you will make your mind to be occupied so it can not keep its process of excessive thinking. It's simple, but it won't shut down your thoughts that easy, so you must practice it for at least 5 up to 10 minutes the first times. Then you should try 15 up to 20 minutes and 20 is perfect for a daily practice, if you do more, better, but i guess most people here are living an urban life so sometimes not everyone has the time to sit down 1 or 2 hours to meditate.
4) Second and more in-depth Example: Sit down, cross your legs, put your hands down together (you can see how in a video or in google :D) and concentrate on your breathing while also using a "Mantra" and / or a imaginary guide scene (this is more difficult because your mind will try to change this imaginary story to don't let you shut it down). A Mantra is fun to have and I personally prefer it. you can look up on the internet how to create a mantra of your own, which is pretty easy, but there are also mantras you can use. For example, there is one Mantra I found last month that goes like this: when you inhale you think "So..." and when you exhale "Ham...". So a Mantra is basically thoughts of pronunciation you can focus on to get your mind out of its usual work of bringing other random thoughts to you, as I said before, is like getting your mind to be occupied.
5) The third example is the most simple one, but is hard as stated before, and is just to sit down, look at a point somewhere in the room, and just try not to think of anything. This one, in particular, is a must do at least for 20 minutes, not less because is harder to meditate without a Focus Practice like the other methods. The good thing about this method is that in your daily life you will always encounter many situations, objects and living beings for your mind to judge and create Thoughts so this method will make you be more like a "rock" against any situation and your mind will stay shut down for longer. It's the most simple of those 3 I've done but by far is the most rewarding.
That's why a majority of successful people practise meditation.

Instead of meditating, I've found more success by just being mindful throughout my day. I constantly bring my focus back to the present moment. For example, while sitting in traffic, I focus on the hum of the engine, the cars and drivers around me, and sometimes the little dandelion growing through the crack in the asphalt. While doing dishes, I pay attention to the sound of the water, the smell of the dish soap etc. This withdraws attention from the thinking mind and slowly that voice in the head gets softer.

I highly recommend passive forms of meditation, like transcendental meditation. Highly forceful styles of meditation, like Zen practices, tend to increase stress and anxiety by forcing you to control mental activity that shouldn't be...like simple thoughts. Modern Americans, who have very hectic and energetic lives, should focus on the passive forms if for no other reason than this: those that learn passive styles tend to keep up the practice while those trying more forceful styles tend to stop the practice early on.

Here's an fMRI study showing a distinct difference between more forceful, mind focus mediation, and the more passive, sound/mantra based styles: http://www.amsciepub.com/doi/abs/10.2466/02.04.22.PMS.111.4.291-306

A note from someone who actually studies the brain for a living:
The Default Mode Network (DMN) is NOT "activated during rest". The default mode network is what neuroscientists propose is the actual RESTING STATE of the brain. It isn't "activated". It just "is". The default mode network is so interesting because it shows that the brain is actually constantly working hard, 100% of the time. The DMN does not "improve memory, self-awareness, and goal-setting". The DMN doesn't improve anything at all. It's what our brains are constantly doing when we think we're resting! Be careful when talking about the brain, especially when you have no neuroscientific background or experience at all.

When starting off you will realize that you're brain has a strong habit to constantly think about something and it's hard to fight that habit. Sorry, but there is not much conclusive evidence for the benefits for meditation, as vast majority of studies are poor quality (and there is overall "replication crisis" in psychology). Search stuff from Cochrane database or other database of meta-analysis, it's the best we have. Not to be too pessimistic, no adverse effects of meditation are shown and there is some weak evidence for meditation's benefits on many (though not all) fields, and intuitively (I meditate myself) meditation seems to make sense. I do recommend people to try out meditation, I'm just saying that here, as usually, AsapScience is not a reliable way to sum results of research but rather sensationalistic pop-science. Then again, if people want definitive answers, it is still a lot better to make them based on individual studies instead of personal anecdotes or societal beliefs. AsapScience is better than most of your friends' opinion.

The very core principle of meditation is to gain self-realization (Enlightenment). 
Today, this is oftenly misunderstood. Surely meditation has many undeniable benefits, but for serious practitioners who are in search of reality, meditation is more about attaining desirelessness, detachment, and ultimately residing in the natural state which is known as "Self, Tao, Source, or God" whatever name you wish to give it. 

Ancient sages like Buddha, Lao Tzu, Ashtavakra Gita, Ramana Maharashi etc. all meant the same thing. Attachments and desires leave the mind restless, clinging to external objects. When the attention falls back to one self, mind becomes quiet and abides in its source. Only by watching the mind and clearing its impurities, we discover ourselves as the watcher. It goes beyond this, but ultimately the Self is the only reality. All else is temporary and arises from the Self. 
This sums up my years of study and practice in eastern ancient philosophy.

I'm not sure about the telomere, i study this in my biology class and normally, after each cell division (a normal one, i mean mitosis), a tiny piece of each telomere is lost, so a somatic cell has a life expectancy determined by the telomere length and it shrinks after each division that the cell made. Of course the cell wich gives gametes (meiosis), or cancerous cell (but it's pathologic then) express the telomerase enzyme which increase the length of the telomere. So i don't think that it affects telomerase in somatic cell, otherwise every cell in our body would have an eternal life that wouldn't be good, given that errors in transcription will finally not be corrected, and so the cell may become cancerous.
